title: Meghan Markle, Prince Harry, Kate Middleton, and Prince William are starring in a commercial written by 'Love Actually' director Richard Curtis
text:
Meghan Markle, Prince Harry, Kate Middleton, and Prince William are starring in a TV commercial to promote the National Health Service's new mental health initiative, "Every Mind Matters."

Although the "Fab Four" don't appear on screen, they narrated the mini-film, which aired on multiple channels across the UK on Monday evening.

Read more: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry just took a big step in establishing their own royal legacy away from Prince William and Kate Middleton

"Everyone knows that feeling. When life gets on top of us," William can be heard saying at the beginning of the clip.

"All over the country, millions of us face challenges to our mental health. At all ages, at all intensities, and for all sorts of reasons."

"Your brother, your mother, your friend, colleague, or your neighbor," Harry adds. "Waiting. Wondering. Hoping. Hurting.

"We think there is nothing to be done, nothing we can do about it."

"But that is so wrong," Markle says.

"There are things we can do. From today, there's a new way to help turn things around. Every Mind Matters will show you simple ways to look after your mental health."

Middleton then says: "It will get you started with a free online plan designed to help you deal with stress, boost your mood, improve your sleep, and feel more in control."

The commercial, which was written by "Love Actually" director Richard Curtis, reportedly caused the new NHS website to crash for a brief period after it aired on Monday evening.

"The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have supported Every Mind Matters by voicing this special film showing how we can all look after our mental health," a spokesperson for the couples wrote on Instagram.

The content of the commercial won't be surprising to royal fans. After all, mental health is the primary focus of their "Heads Together" initiative, under which they launched the successful textline service, "Shout."

However, it marked the royal couples' first project together since Markle and Harry split from William and Middleton's Royal Foundation charity back in July.

Harry and Markle are in the process of establishing their own charity, Sussex Royal, for which details are yet to be announced.

Royal commentator Richard Fitzwilliams previously told Insider that the charity is likely to focus on environmental issues, community, and gender equality, and will have strong links to the couple's social media.

"It is certainly a curious name for a charity but it has a contemporary feel to it and it ties in with their hugely popular Instagram account, which now has over 9 million followers. So this makes sense in a world dominated by social media," he said.
